AI store can be quite resilient
depending on how you deploy it uh we
view this cache as opportunistic and and
that means that it's not a single point
of failure the cache clients will simply
fall back to the origin the source of
truth um in the event of a missing
object or an expired object or in the
event of some sort of system outage um
so it's not in the failure path and that
was part of our uh requirement in this
so let's say for example this is London
let's say we have several data centers
in London Um you've got workloads

users um within that geography can

Okay Now if we apply that principle back
to this picture and deploy regional
caches on a global
scale you can see how powerful this
could be and just how much impact it
might have As a side note I'll point out
here this is a good opportunity to
visually describe why the write through
cache is the model for this So this
cache is essentially a write once read
once or read never cache Every time a
session comes through we assume that
data is modified Therefore the cache
object is is effectively invalidated for
the next session Um and so let's say
you're here in London you launch a
session and u next week you're in
Seattle right So in London at the end of
your session the object is written to
the local cache or rather the regional
cache Uh and the object is also written
to the source of truth the origin in the
cloud uh when you travel to Seattle and
launch your session that that object in
London is really of no use because it's
so far away and that would defeat the
purpose for the latency side of this and
so it'll just pull from uh the the
origin again and then invalidate the
object over in London So
um that's the
uh yeah that's the global scale of
things about the impact measurable
impact So we ran a live canary across
three regions which represented just a
small fraction of our total
estate And so with about 400,000 samples
over a period of two weeks we confirmed
our thesis that faster uploads and
faster downloads brought us some serious
wins in terms of the user experience uh
and in terms of our system capacity and
efficiency So specifically um we saw
download throughput increase by about
51% which materialized as a concrete 35%
reduction in the download transfer time
So that translates to happier users
waiting less time to resume their next
session Sounds like kind of a small
thing You'd be surprised how a few
seconds make a big difference Um so we
regarding cost this is kind of
interesting I don't have a slide on the

egress usage patterns and the observed

canary we anticipate reducing the egress
by hundreds of pabytes per year And I'll

what that might
cost So we expected most of the
performance gains here to be on the

the upload side the average throughput
from the client side saw some
performance improvements as well Um some
of that was expected some of it was a
bit of a surprise So we we saw an
increase in that speed on average by 45%
Again that's from the client to the
cache Um but since this is a right-h the
upload transfer time improvements in the
end are pretty nominal and and again
that's kind of how how we would expect

through cache is to make sure that the
data is written on the back end to
ensure consistency that kind of limits
the uh opportunity for overall upload
performance gains but still we saw we
saw some wins um I actually was quite
pleased to see that we didn't add
latency by putting a cache in the middle
of that upload Um and so we we did some
analysis We've still got some more work

the way the cache uh is able to use keep
a life connections to reuse um TCP
connections as opposed to each
